metadata.name: Deconstructions #243
metadata.description:
Deconstructions is a further experiment with blending 3 colors and 3 different textures to create structural/abstract compositions. It's a search for beauty within asymmetrical/unsynchronized forms and disharmonic structures.


Probabilities;

- 18 compositions with variations.

- 2 background colors.

- 3 different particle starting placements.

- 21 different base color palettes. (1 monochrome) 

- 2 different alpha types; tangential & randomized.

- Different edges.

- Several starting positions and styles (wavy or straight).

Additional animation features with different shapes, angles, direction and style.


In live mode, press ‚Äòs‚Äô to save as .png (1500x2000 px)

It can take up to a minute to render or longer in low-performance computers. Enjoy the process!


Made with p5.js

Ilgƒ±n ƒ∞√ß√∂z√º, May 2022
@distcollective

metadata.name: Mina #3
metadata.description:
A generative series of a-symmetric compositions.

Mina is a search for new textures created by combining 3 colors with 3 different mathematical equations.

Observe how Mina blends and creates its textures in time.

Probabilities;

- 18 color palettes.

- 2 background colors.

- 4 line placements.

- 14 different compositions, most of them have variations.


Made with p5.js

Ilgƒ±n ƒ∞√ß√∂z√º, December 2021
@distcollective

metadata.name: fxhash x thi.ng project template #43
metadata.description:
THIS IS NOT AN ARTWORK (at least not intentional)!

This NFT acts as a donation/funding mechanism for a new project template Git repo, providing a compact, ready-to-go scaffolding for generative art projects aimed at the fx(hash) platform/marketplace.

https://github.com/thi-ng/fxhash-tpl

This template evolved over time and has served as basis for some of the author's own NFT projects (https://www.fxhash.xyz/u/toxi). The template is aimed at TypeScript (but can be easily adapted to plain JavaScript) and, at the time of writing, uses Vite as dev & build tool, ensuring an altogether great & speedy workflow with minimal fuzz.

(In the future, I'm aiming to provide an alternative version for more advanced hybrid projects using TypeScript, Zig (https://ziglang.org) and WebAssembly (https://webassembly.org/)...)

Framework agnostic

Even though several packages from the https://thi.ng/umbrella ecosystem are used to provide various essential overarching functionality, the template is organized in such a way that the main parts are completely framework-agnostic. You should be able to easily plug in your own toolkit of choice, however I cannot promise to provide support for this myself (though happy to accept PRs, also in terms of further docs, how-tos, guides etc.)

Example project

A tiny, fully documented throwaway example sketch is included, illustrating the following:

- Overall project structure & build commands
- FXhash related setup
- Static & dynamic configuration and state (re)initialization (via dependency graph)
- FXhash PRNG wrapper & utilities
- Canvas & SVG conversion/export/download
- 2D geometry creation, transformation & drawing
- Basic vector algebra example usage


Keyboard shortcuts

- space :  pause/play animation
- x : download canvas as PNG
- s : download SVG version

In case of doubt, it's this example project what is used here for minting. The funding, however, will be used for the further maintenance of both this project template and supporting my other open source work. 20% are also donated to the FXhash development team itself.

Thank you for your support! üôèüòç

metadata.name: Grunks #15
metadata.description: Grunks Gonna Grunk!

metadata.name: Shifted Blocks #40
metadata.description:
The art is programmatically drawn using basic shapes, math, random using p5js.

To save image:

press '0' || 'd' to save image is default quality
press '1' || 's' to save image as '613x775px'
press '2' || 'm' to save image as '735x930px'
press '3' to save image as '883x1116px'
press '4' || 'p' to save image as '1059x1339px'
press '5' to save image as '1271x1607px'
press '6' to save image as '1525x1928px'
press '7' || 'h' to save image as '1831x2314px'

press 'f' to see art in full screen.

created by: https://twitter.com/mrmecroni or NotaArtist

metadata.name: Breakers #90
metadata.description:
Companion project to Neural Collapse (#15780), for the collectors of my previous efforts.
A study on the repetition and stacking of a simple dynamic structure, this time inside a cylinder.

Everything procedurally generated at runtime.

Interactivity : 
- You can click on each individual breaker to open or close them. The problem is it will toggle others.
- Press and hold the mouse button to slightly move the viewpoint. The previous interaction not being disabled while doing that, you get some switching all over the place as a bonus bug/feature.

- Press "a" to increase quality of the antialiasing (3 levels), at the cost of performances. If you don't like jaggies and your machine can take it.
- Export a PNG capture at various resolutions by pressing the number keys 1 to 9 (top row or numpad, and only in live mode, after pressing "open"). Resolutions ranges from 720 to 7680 pixels. I recommend starting with "4".

GPU recommended. Best performances on Chrome in general.

metadata.name: Polar Grid #207
metadata.description:
Polar Grid is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022.

This is a study of color, motion, and composition, and an homage to cinema as an artform. Colorful shapes overlap and pulse in a ever repeating dance. An abstracted movie experience. Each color palette in the series (except one) is inspired by a different film director (if you want a real challenge, see how many you can guess without looking at the feature names).

The palettes were extracted from movie stills or movie posters and fine tuned by hand. As often, I have to thank independent tool makers for their indirect help. My gratitude goes to David Aerne for FarbV√©lo and Fabrizio Bianchi for Coolors.

The code for Polar Grid is based on early iterations of what ultimately became my carat series. Both projects come from the same fascination for color as a system, even though I used a different approach here. You could call this a carat prequel.

The animation is done using a technique called polar noise. This makes it so the motion of all elements ends up repeating in the same amount of time. This is useful for generating motion that loops perfectly while still appearing organic. In this particular case, the animation repeats every œÄ √ó 100 seconds.

A challenge in building any generative system is to find the right balance between coherence and variety. I designed the system with the large edition size in mind. During development I generated hundreds of iterations and tweaked my code to make sure that every iteration is truly unique and fits the overall aesthetic of the collection.

I truly hope you will enjoy your own little abstract movie.

‚Äî Rapha√´l de Courville


Released: July 6th 2022

Medium: p5.js, html canvas, css

Reference: sk220621


**About the artist**

Rapha√´l de Courville is a generative artist, streamer, and educator. His artistic work is an exploration of generative systems, patterns, interactivity, and time. Born in Paris, he lives and works in Berlin.


**Instructions**

- Click/Tap or press SPACEBAR to play and pause the animation

In Fullscreen mode (desktop only):
- Press UP or DOWN arrows to adjust image quality (Note: this can affect performance)
- Press F to hide/show the browser UI

metadata.name: Mediterranean #223
metadata.description:
How diverse can nature be?

Created with p5js.
Code takes a few minutes to complete. Needs a good CPU.
Works faster on Chrome browser.
For high-res images: Type a resolution multiplier number on live view. If you type 2, it will render 2 times larger than your screen size. Press "s" to save.

metadata.name: bad saturn  #50
metadata.description:
-- bad saturn
-- alexthescott
-- 22/6/29

-- ty to @aebrer for this maths
rng = stat(6)
if rng == "" then
rng=tostr(rnd(-1)\1)..","..tostr(1+rnd(3)\1)..","..tostr(rnd(16)\1)..","
end
rng_vals = {}
c_num = ""
for i=1,#rng do
 if sub(rng,i,i) != "," then
  c_num = c_num..sub(rng,i,i)
 else 
  add(rng_vals,tonum(c_num))
  c_num = ""
 end
end

srand(rng_vals[1])

function forward()
	v=c[1]
	del(c,v)
	c[#c+1]=v
	pal(c,1)
end

p1={7,6,135,10,138,11,139,3,131,12,140,1,129,130,128,0}
p2={7,135,10,9,15,143,142,137,14,136,8,2,130,133,128,0}
p3={7,15,143,142,14,8,136,137,9,10,135,138,11,139,12,140}

p={p1,p2,p3}
c=p[rng_vals[2]]
pal(c,1)

for i=1,rnd(rng_vals[3]) do
	forward()
end

t=rnd()
r=rnd()
p=rnd()
c,s=sin,cos
cls()
::‚ô•::
if time()<2 then
	print("bad saturn",46,59)
	print("seed:"..rng_vals[1],46,65)
else
	party=rnd()<(1+sin(0.5-t))/2
	for i=0,1000 do
		x=rnd(128)
		y=rnd(128)
		-- radial burn
		if not party then
			a=atan2((64-x)/128,(64-y)/128)
			x2=x-cos(a)
			y2=y-sin(a)
			pset(x2,y2,max(pget(x,y)-1,0))
		-- og burn
		else
			pset(x,y,max(pget(x,y)-1,0))
		end
	end
	for o=1,6 do
		j=o*13
		for i=1,128 do
		 
			k=o/12
			a=(i-1)/128
			b=i/128
			x,y=64+s(r+k)*c(a+t)*j,64+s(a)*j
			u,v=64-c(p+k)*c(b)*j,64+s(b)*j
			line(x,y,u,v,10-o)
		end
	end
	t+=0.001
	r+=0.0002
	r+=0.0006
	if rnd(0.7)<(1+sin(t/2))/2 then
		if t*100%8<=4 then
			w=3+rnd(10)
			h=10+rnd(86)
		else
			w=10+rnd(86)
			h=3+rnd(10)
		end
		x=rnd(128-w)
		y=rnd(128-h)
		xo=rnd(4)*(1-2*(rnd(2)\1))
		yo=rnd(4)*(1-2*(rnd(2)\1))
		sspr(x,y,w,h,x+xo,y+yo,w,h)
	end
	poke(0x5f55,0x6000,8192)
end
flip()
goto ‚ô•

metadata.name: Lazy Kitties #1882
metadata.description:
Welcome to the Lazy Kitties Society!

Be the guardian of these cute kitties born in the Tezos blockchain space.
And please be a part of our Lazy Kitties Society!
https://discord.gg/lazykitties

Let's create a wonderful world with kittens! MEOW!

[Mouse Movement]: Eye Control
[Press 'c' or 'C'] : Kitten's Favorite Cushion (Toggle)
[Press 's' or 'S'] : Save Snapshot (With BG)
[Press 't' or 'T'] : Save Snapshot (Transparent BG)
[Click] : ??

Made with Love & P5.js !
NFT License 2.0
By CSLIM, 2022

metadata.name: Sand Table #86
metadata.description:
Just like a sand jar that you made or played with as a child. A recreation of layered colored sand with star glitter at the "peaks." Rare versions will be all gold and super rare has rainbow shimmer glitter.

Press 's' to take a screenshot. The image size is 1000x1000. 

Features
- 20 color palettes
- 2 color distribution methods
- 4 sand distribution methods
- sand size variation
- noise variables to determine patterns and layers

Rare features
- color sand with gold stars
- all stars instead of sand grains
- all gold glitter with silver stars
- all rainbow glitter with silver stars (super rare)
